trial_identification.studytitle: Use of an antisupine device in the management of positional OSA
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effectiveness of controlled sleep position versus nCPAP in the management of positional obstructive sleep apnoea.

interventions.interventions: A thoracic antisupine device with novel design features will be worn during sleep. At the end of one month a home-based overnight sleep study with the device in situ will be performed. After a one week washout, followed by a month on nCPAP the study will be repeated.
interventions.comparator: Use of the thoracic anti supine band (TASB) nightly for one month was compared with standard treatment nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) for the alternate month;

primaryOutcome.outcome: Apnoea hypopnoea index reduced to clinically acceptable levels (</= 10/h) as measured by the home sleep study and relief of symptoms such as daytime hyersomnolence
primaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the month on the device.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: An overnight sleep study will be performed. Analysis of data will include the period of time spent sleeping in the supine posture. (Success with the anti-supine device <10% sleep in supine).
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: At the end of the one month period.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Adults with positional obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) with at least 10% of sleep in supine and apnoea hypopnoea index (AHI) twice as much in supine and non supine.
